content.description: This is a must do in the canyon! Put your crimp skills to the test. The crux is after the 2nd bolt. Little run between 3rd and 4th bolt but mellow for sure. Good mantle at the top.
content.protection: Bring webbing for the anchor(Tree) and there are 4 bolts to clip.
content.location: Located at Goldfinger Wall. It's the bolted line to the right of Goldfingers. Same start as Goldfingers but head right...

content.description:
Many

Goldenfingers

climbers have witnessed the squirrels using this gulley for travel to and from the rim to the forest floor.

Soloed many times before.

If you like dirty chimneys you'll love this lil' beauty. Lots of crystals make for some fun moves when your not climbing in the back of this dirty gash.
content.protection: Top-rope. I would imagine a standard rack would suffice for a lead. Fergs spider stick.
content.location:
This is the chimney/gulley to the right of

The Stone they Rejected

.  Crystals abound on this gash. Descent from bolted anchor at top.

content.description:
The crux might be staying on the line. But if you do it's quite fun.

Pull up into Otherworld and step out right onto cool crystals and horizontals. Keep to the right of the gash staying on the arete. Near the top step back over to the left and climb up a wide section of rock to the anchor.
content.location: This is the arete immediately to the right of Squirrel Highway.

content.description: On the right face of the wall you will see a finger crack that starts about 10-15 feet above the ground.  This is your goal.  Startalmost below the bolted line to the right, attain the leftward diagonalling cracks and move left until you can make the finger crack.  The bolt protects the crux.  However, the funnest part is the lunge for the flake near the top.  I later tried to climb the direct line and realized why you start right.
content.protection: Large slings for trees at the top.  1 draw for the climb, and TCU's for the crack.

content.description:
If it looks easy, its probably hard!!

A puzzling start on the smoothest of granite. A route that demands attention, precision, and a will to live. Thin and begging for balance,

Golden Oldie

climbs past three bolts to a right facing flake. Repeat after me: Strenuous!
content.protection: Three bolts to a two bolt anchor.

content.description:
Climb the arete using knobs and small crystals. Gain a slab stance about half way up and clip the only bolt. Friction your way up the remaining face aiming for a thin crack. Top it out and give yourself a high five.

Back-wall dabbing the start is highly discouraged.
content.location:
On the far left side of the main

Goldenfingers Wall

just left of

Golden Oldie

content.description: Start in the chimney and move out onto a ledge between the arete and the chimney.  Follow the crack to the bulge and pull over to the top.  Nothing really strenuous or technical.
content.protection: Nuts, a pin at the top, and some medium cams to build an anchor if you're not going to walk off.
content.location: Climbs the right side of the arete on the east face of the Goldenfingers Wall.  Start in a chimney, and move left into a crack.  A pin is visible just under the horizon.  There is a walk off to the southeast.

climbs.name: Arete Juliete
climbs.fa: Scott Unice, Julie Gustin, Gordon Oakeson, 1988

content.description:
Above and around the corner from

Goldfinger

is a rounded and striking arete. This blank and lightly featured face is

Arete Juliete

. Particular protection and intimidating moves make this line a bold undertaking. This climb sees low amounts of traffic yielding flaky and brittle terrain.

Start off-balance with blank feet and blunt hands. A dynamic move gains a long shallow edge. Rock onto this small ledge, place a piece then ride the arete up and left past a bolt. Stay low and on the face avoiding the temptation to rock over too soon. Squeeze the blunt arete and slab up and left across the face. Clip another bolt and keep trust in what follows! A few sketchy moves unveil a good surprise, mantle up and over at the lines apex.
content.protection:
Two draws, small/med. stoppers, and gear from .5-#2 Black Diamond. Build an anchor on top using the hand sized pieces. Walk-off or scramble down to

Goldfinger's

anchors.
content.location:
Above and Around from

Goldfinger

is a large and rounding arete. Start on it's left side in front of a few broken boulders.

content.description:
Wild

Ferguson

funk up an arete. As interesting as it's

neighbor

, albeit more direct, this mixed line offers a touch of everything.

Start on a belay platform and scurry up to a thin crack on the left-side of the face. Follow cracks up 5 feet to a large, scooping horn. Pull into an obvious crack and follow it through the face to the top of the buttress. You'll come across some thoughtful gear with good stances and a single bolt that protects the crux. Originally done going straight up the thin crack, using the only the arete and avoiding completely avoiding anything to the right or the corner.

Descend via a quick and easy walk-off back and to the left.

This route has an anchor that comes and goes? People like to steal shiny things?  Be prepared to build your own anchor, clip the pre-slung block, or do both. Easy to top-rope.
content.protection: A light rack with stress on micro nuts and cams. . You won't need more than two or three pieces, all small, but you may have to build or back up the slung block at the top with anypiece from a 1/2 to 2 inches.
content.location:
Located at the

Goldfingers Wall

.

Arete Bernadette

sits up, left, and around the corner (south east) from

Arete Juliete

. Look for a clean, obvious face with a wavy crack and single bolt.
